From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia


2024 film by Kiah Roache-Turner
This article is about the 2024 horror film. For the 1973 caper film, see The Sting.
StingTheaterical release posterDirected byKiah Roache-TurnerWritten byKiah Roache-TurnerProduced byJamie HiltonMichael PontinChris BrownStarringAlyla BrownePenelope MitchellRyan CorrJermaine FowlerCinematographyBrad ShieldEdited by
Jeff Cummings
Luke Doolan
Kiah Roache-Turner
Music byAnna DrubichProductioncompaniesAlignSee PicturesPictures in ParadiseScreen AustraliaDistributed by
Well Go USA Entertainment (United States)
StudioCanal (Select territories)
Release date
April 12, 2024 (2024-04-12) (United States)
Running time91 minutes[1]CountriesAustraliaUnited StatesLanguageEnglishBox office$825,797[2]
Sting is a 2024 horror film written and directed by Kiah Roache-Turner. It stars Ryan Corr, Alyla Browne, Penelope Mitchell, Robyn Nevin, Noni Hazelhurst, Silvia Colloca, Danny Kim, and Jermaine Fowler, and follows a young girl who raises an alien spider, which then begins to terrorize her apartment complex. The film was released in the United States on April 12, 2024.


Plot[edit]
This article needs a plot summary. Please add one in your own words. (April 2024) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)
Cast[edit]

Ryan Corr as Ethan
Alyla Browne as Charlotte
Penelope Mitchell as Heather
Robyn Nevin as Gunterddd
Noni Hazelhurst as Helga
Silvia Colloca as Maria
Danny Kim as Eric
Jermaine Fowler as Frank
Production[edit]
Filming took place in Australia, and wrapped in February 2023.[3][4]

Release[edit]
The film was released on April 12, 2024 in the United States by Well Go USA Entertainment, and by StudioCanal in the United Kingdom, Australia, New Zealand, France, Germany, Switzerland, and Benelux.[5]

Reception[edit]
Box office[edit]
Sting was released from 975 theaters worldwide and it gross $825,797 in five days.[6]

Critical response[edit]
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 69% of 59 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 6/10. The website's consensus reads: "Sting should satisfy horror fans in the mood for a creature feature, even if the end results won't likely linger in the memory."[7] Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 52 out of 100, based on seven critics, indicating "mixed or average" reviews.[8]
